body: We need to be a little bit careful with `unicode_literals`, because that converts every string in the file, which can have unintended side effects. I've had a scan down the file, and there are no obvious problems, but I'd like us to do some manual testing of this before it lands, because these modules are poorly covered by automated tests.

**Test results for commit ca15c23 merged into master**
Platform: linux2
- python2.7: OK
- python3.1: OK (libraries not available: matplotlib pymongo qt wx wx.aui zmq)
- python3.2: OK (libraries not available: pymongo wx wx.aui)

Not available for testing: python2.6

For manual testing, three commands I'd like to check work:

```
%pycat foo.py   # use any reasonably complex Python file you have to hand
1/0                   # trigger a regular traceback
raise = 2           # and a SyntaxError traceback
```

The focus is on Python 2, since this shouldn't change anything for Python 3. Also, cycle through the three traceback modes using `%xmode` and repeat the last two tests.
It all seems to be OK on Linux, with Python 2.7.3 and with 2.6.7.
In magic_paste text is sent to colorize from the clipboard. What happens on non-windows platforms? Will  clipboard_get return a str or unicode. If str what should I assume about encoding?

I think some of the new functionality in `IPython.utils.io` is redundant with stuff in `IPython.utils.openpy` - can you look into merging it into that module?

This PR has also picked up a conflict with master, so we'll need to rebase it before we can merge.

`clipboard_get()` on Linux appears to retrieve misformed unicode, it looks like this is a bug in Tkinter. On OS X, it's calling a subprocess, so it will likely be in bytes; that should really be fixed within clipboard_get.
I've filed a Python issue for the problems with Tkinter clipboard_get(): http://bugs.python.org/issue14777

I'll look into it. I'm travelling so it will not be before sunday.

> This PR has also picked up a conflict with master, so we'll need to rebase it before we can merge.

Thomas Kluyver skrev 2012-05-11 00:31:

> `clipboard_get()` on Linux appears to retrieve misformed unicode, it looks like this is a bug in Tkinter. On OS X, it's calling a subprocess, so it will likely be in bytes; that should really be fixed within clipboard_get.

I have added casts to unicode for clipboard_get on Linux and OSX. I used 
DEFAULT_ENCODING.

How do I use the demo mode? In the docs there is a reference to docs/examples/core/demo-exercizer.py but that file seems to be gone.

I think demo mode is broken with this PR as is but I do not know how to use it.
Is demo mode the same thing as this? http://ipython.org/ipython-doc/dev/interactive/reference.html#interactive-demos-with-ipython

Thomas Kluyver skrev 2012-05-15 22:16:

> Is demo mode the same thing as this? http://ipython.org/ipython-doc/dev/interactive/reference.html#interactive-demos-with-ipython

yes that description should be enough. I found this one 
http://ipython.org/ipython-doc/rel-0.12.1/api/generated/IPython.lib.demo.html?highlight=demo#IPython.lib.demo
I've got the problem with Tkinter fixed for Python 3.3/3.2.4/2.7.4. I'm now a CPython contributor! :-)
I just rebased from master 2caea25 after the magics PR.
The magics refactoring broke several magic commands (pdef, pdoc, psource, pfile) commit a71d86a fixes this

**Test results for commit a71d86a merged into master**
Platform: linux2
- python2.7: OK
- python3.1: OK (libraries not available: cython matplotlib pymongo qt wx wx.aui zmq)
- python3.2: OK (libraries not available: cython pymongo wx wx.aui)

Not available for testing: python2.6

Hey guys, just touching bases on this.  How far do you think we are from merging it?  We have so many PRs in flight that I'm a bit worried and don't want to create multiple conflicts everywhere...  We also need to begin thinking about 0.13 sometime soon...

@fperez : I'll want to see both manual and automatic testing of this on all three main platforms, on Python 2 & 3. It's useful to make these bits properly unicode aware in Python 2, but there's definite potential for breaking things - not least because in working around Python 2's model, it's easy to break things for Python 3 where the extra complexity was never needed.

For manual testing, start with my comment here: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/1715#issuecomment-5609988 - but the scope has now expanded, and we'll need to test other bits like the debugger as well.

**Test results for commit 7bcb9aa (can't merge cleanly)**
Platform: linux2
- python2.7: OK (libraries not available: tornado)
- python3.1: Failed, log at https://gist.github.com/2907745 (libraries not available: cython matplotlib pymongo qt wx wx.aui zmq)
- python3.2: Failed, log at https://gist.github.com/2907746 (libraries not available: cython pymongo wx wx.aui)

Not available for testing: python2.6
Awesome work, @takluyver, thanks!  Indeed, let's let this one settle well before we go breaking things :)
Did a new rebase on master.

Here is a list of functions that are affected by the PR. I include the ones from  https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/1715#issuecomment-5609988

%run failing script from path with non-ascii
%run failing script with non-ascii characters in str **doc**
%run failing script with non-ascii characters in unicode **doc**
%run -d script from path with non-ascii
%run -d script with non-ascii characters in str **doc**
%run -d script with non-ascii characters in unicode **doc**

Non-ascii characters in demo-mode  
@fperez I have done some light testing of the demo mode but I don't know how it is supposed to work.

? of object from path with non-ascii characters
? of object with non-ascii characters in str **doc**
? of object with non-ascii characters in unicode **doc**
?? of object from path with non-ascii characters
?? of object with non-ascii characters in str **doc**
?? of object with non-ascii characters in unicode **doc**

%debug !Trigger exception in source with non-ascii characters in sourcecode

%pdef obj
%pdoc obj
%pfile obj     !show file where obj is defined
%pinfo obj
%pinfo2 obj  
%psource obj   !show source of obj
%pycat foo.py  !show syntax highlighted code in foo.py, use file containing non-ascii characters

At prompt:
1/0 #trigger regular traceback
raise = 2 #Trigger SyntaxError

I have tried this manually in 2.7 on windows and it seems to work.
I'll get onto testing those things later in Linux. I'd like someone to also check them in Python 3 on Windows.

I get problems with %debug and %pdef on python 3. But the other stuff from the list above seems to work.

The problem with %pdef does not seem to be related to my unicode changes but something else. I opened issue #1914 for this.

I will try to look into the %debug stuff tomorrow.

**Test results for commit 2805245 merged into master**
Platform: linux2
- python2.7: OK
- python3.2: OK (libraries not available: cython matplotlib oct2py pygments pymongo rpy2 wx wx.aui)

Not available for testing: python2.6, python3.1
Tests look clean, do you guys think you want this in time for 0.13?

I'd lean towards putting it in 0.14, because it touches quite a lot of code, and I'd like to make sure it's well tested on the 3 major platforms and 2 major Python versions (sorry, I haven't found time to hold up my end of the manual testing on this). Also, @jstenar's last comment suggests he's still working on some bits.

But then, I'm not seeing the bug, so I don't know how annoying it is. ;)
Sounds good, let's go for 0.14 then unless @jstenar has a good case to revert that decision.  Indeed at this point we should be very careful on touching the more delicate parts of the internals.
